doc.abstracts: On April 1, May 10, and October 3, 1991, Robert S. McNamara was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by John Lewis, Richard Webb, and Devesh Kapur. During his tenure at the Bank, Mr. McNamara served as president from 1968 to 1981. His name was proposed to the Board on November 29, 1967, after which he presented a budget and decided to prepare a 5-year plan within the first year of his tenure. The new plan called for a doubling of the borrowings, lending, and a corresponding expansion of the staff and budget of the World Bank. His transcript discusses his view of the World Bank as a development agency not as a commercial bank. He discusses country division chiefs playing significant roles in projects; thus leading to his restructuring of the World Bank to give more power to country staff rather than to project staff.
